subjects.title: Indian Polity
subjects.description: Master Indian Constitution, Governance, and Political System

topics.title: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP)
topics.description: Part IV (Articles 36-51) - State's TO-DO list for Social & Economic Democracy

subTopics.title: DPSP ‚Äî Introduction & Complete Module
subTopics.description: Complete module covering origin, features, classification, and 150 questions

content.heading: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP)
content.body: Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) ‚Äî Part IV (Articles 36‚Äì51). Think of DPSP as the constitution's TO-DO list for the State: positive, policy-guiding directives to establish social and economic democracy and a Welfare State. DPSP are fundamental in governance (Article 37) but are non-justiciable in courts. They were adopted into the Indian Constitution in 1950, having been influenced by Spain and Ireland (GOI Act 1935 called them 'Instrument of Instructions').
highlights: Article 37: Fundamental in governance but non-justiciable
Positive instructions to State (not negative like FR)

content.heading: Part IV ‚Äî Directive Principles of State Policy
content.body: DPSP form Part IV of the Indian Constitution, comprising Articles 36 to 51. These 16 articles (originally) were adopted on 26 January 1950 when the Constitution came into effect. Their primary role is to guide the State in policy formulation, lawmaking, and overall governance of the country.
highlights: Role: Guide State policy and lawmaking

content.heading: Origin Chain: SPAIN ‚Üí IRELAND ‚Üí INDIA
content.body: Spain was the first country to adopt directive principles in their constitution. Ireland later borrowed and adapted these concepts. Finally, India borrowed the concept from Ireland's constitution when framing our own Constitution. The Government of India Act 1935 used the term 'Instrument of Instructions' which directly influenced how DPSP were framed in the Indian Constitution.
highlights: Spain: First to adopt directive principles

content.heading: 11 Key Features of DPSP
content.body: DPSP have several distinctive characteristics that set them apart from Fundamental Rights. They are addressed to the State (not individuals), contain positive instructions (State must DO actions), and are non-justiciable in courts as per Article 37 (recommended by Tej Bahadur Sapru Committee). However, they are justiciable in the 'Court of the People' through elections and political accountability. DPSP promote social and economic democracy, reduce inequality, establish a Welfare State (Article 38), and encourage inclusive and sustainable growth. While fundamental in governance, they are not self-executory and require legislative implementation (e.g., MGNREGA, RTE Act). Article 40 served as the precursor to Panchayati Raj Institutions (73rd Amendment).
highlights: Fundamental in governance but not enforceable
Not self-executory (need laws like MGNREGA, RTE)

content.title: R-N-A-L-S ‚Äî Thinkers Who Commented on DPSP

breakdown.meaning: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called DPSP 'novel features' of the Constitution
Called DPSP 'the conscience of the Constitution'
Called DPSP 'life-giving provisions of the Constitution'
Criticized DPSP as 'a cheque payable at the convenience of the bank (State)'
Articles: 38, 39, 39A, 41, 42, 43, 43A, 47 ‚Äî Focus on social & economic justice, welfare state, equal distribution, workers' rights
Articles: 40, 43, 43B, 46, 47, 48 ‚Äî Focus on village panchayats, cottage industries, prohibition, cow protection, rural development
Articles: 44, 45, 48, 48A, 49, 50, 51 ‚Äî Focus on UCC, education, environment protection, monuments, separation of judiciary, international peace

content.heading: DPSP ‚Äî Complete Exam Summary
content.body: Part IV | Articles 36‚Äì51 | Origin: Spain ‚Üí Ireland ‚Üí India (S-I-I). Key features: Addressed to State, Positive instructions, Non-justiciable (Sapru Committee), Promote welfare state & social-economic democracy, Not self-executory, Precursor of PRIs. Classification: S-G-L (Socialist, Gandhian, Liberal-Intellectual). Thinkers: R-N-A-L-S (Rau-Novel-Austin-Life-Shah). Important articles: 37 (fundamental in governance), 38 (welfare state), 40 (PRIs), 44 (UCC), 48A (environment). Implementation: MGNREGA (Art 41), RTE Act (Art 45). Triple NON: Non-justiciable, Non-enforceable, Non-self-executory.
highlights: Thinkers: R-N-A-L-S (Rau, Novel, Austin, Life, Shah)

subTopics.title: Article 36 ‚Äî Definition of State (DPSP)
subTopics.description: Article 36 defines 'State' for the purpose of Part IV (DPSP).

content.heading: What is Article 36?
content.body: Article 36 defines 'STATE' for the purpose of Part IV (DPSP). It states that the meaning of 'State' in Part IV is the same as in Part III (Article 12), unless the context otherwise requires.
highlights: Meaning is same as Article 12 by default
Provides contextual flexibility: 'unless the context otherwise requires'

content.heading: Why Article 36 Exists
content.body: To ensure clarity about who is responsible for implementing DPSP and to allow flexible interpretation when context demands. It keeps Part IV self-contained and legally precise.
highlights: Ensures clarity on the 'state' responsible for DPSP implementation
Provides flexibility where context differs from Article 12
Helps interpret DPSP scope during legal and policy discussions

content.heading: Core Meaning
content.body: STATE under DPSP = STATE under Fundamental Rights (Article 12) by default. That includes Government bodies, Legislatures, Local Authorities, and Other Authorities under government control.
highlights: STATE = State under Article 12 by default
Includes Government of India, Union and State Legislatures, Local Authorities, and other authorities

content.title: Quick Facts
points: Article 36 = Definition Article, not a Directive Principle.
Same meaning as Article 12, except when context changes.
Used to determine who must follow DPSP.
Judiciary is NOT included in 'State' unless performing public functions.
Private bodies are NOT 'State' unless under deep government control.

content.heading: Article 36 & Article 12 Relationship
content.body:
ARTICLE 12  ‚Üí  Definition of State for FR
ARTICLE 36  ‚Üí  Same Definition for DPSP
Both = G-P-G-L-A structure

content.heading: G-P-G-L-A Memory Framework
content.body:
G = Government of India
P = Parliament of India
G = Government of States
L = Legislature of States
A = All Local + Other Authorities

content.heading: Twin Articles Visual
content.body:
Article 12 ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñ∂ Meaning of State
Article 36 ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ñ∂ Uses same meaning
(Twin Articles üëØ)

breakdown.meaning: Local bodies and other authorities under government control

content.heading: Example: Article 38 (Welfare State)
content.body: Article 38: Here 'State' means Government of India + State Governments because welfare policies are made by them.

content.heading: Example: Article 51 (International Peace)
content.body: Article 51: Here 'State' refers to India as a nation dealing with international relations.

content.title: Key Cases
points: Ajay Hasia vs Khalid Mujib (1981) ‚Äî defines test for 'other authority' (gov control, funding, monopoly)
Pradeep Kumar Biswas (2002) ‚Äî deep and pervasive control test for 'State' status
Zee Telefilms (2005) ‚Äî private bodies performing public functions may be 'State' in limited contexts

items.value: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)

items.term: Which article gives the meaning of 'State' for FR?
What does 'unless the context otherwise requires' do?
items.value: Gives flexibility to interpret 'State' depending on article context.

items.term: Is Judiciary included in 'State' for Article 36?

items.value: Bodies performing public functions under government control (e.g., LIC, ONGC, Universities).

content.title: Article 36 Revision
points: One-liner: Article 36 = Article 12 meaning of 'State' applied to DPSP.
Keywords: Definition Article, Same as Article 12, Unless context otherwise requires, G-P-G-L-A, Not a directive principle

Yes, if under government control and performing public functions

quiz.prompt: Article 36 defines the meaning of 'State' for which part of the Constitution?
quiz.reason: Article 36 provides the definition of 'State' specifically for Part IV, which contains the Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP).

quiz.prompt: Article 36 uses the same meaning of 'State' as which article?
quiz.reason: Article 36 explicitly states that it uses the same meaning of 'State' as defined in Article 12 for Fundamental Rights.

quiz.prompt: What does the phrase 'unless the context otherwise requires' in Article 36 mean?
options: State can never be interpreted differently
Gives flexibility to interpret 'State' based on article context
quiz.reason: The phrase 'unless the context otherwise requires' provides flexibility, allowing the meaning of 'State' to be interpreted differently depending on the specific context of the DPSP article.

quiz.prompt: Which of the following is NOT included in the definition of 'State' under Article 36?
quiz.reason: Judiciary is not included in the definition of 'State' under Article 12 or Article 36. The definition includes executive and legislative bodies plus other authorities under government control.

quiz.prompt: What is the 'deep and pervasive control' test related to?
quiz.reason: The 'deep and pervasive control' test from Pradeep Kumar Biswas case (2002) is used to determine whether a body qualifies as 'other authority' under the definition of 'State'.

quiz.prompt: Article 36 applies to DPSP articles numbered:
quiz.reason: Article 36 provides the definition of 'State' for all Directive Principles of State Policy, which are contained in Articles 36-51.

quiz.prompt: Which case established the test for determining 'other authority' under Article 36?
quiz.reason: Ajay Hasia vs Khalid Mujib (1981) established the test for determining whether a body qualifies as 'other authority' under the definition of 'State'.

quiz.prompt: The G-P-G-L-A mnemonic represents:
quiz.reason: G-P-G-L-A stands for Government of India, Parliament of India, Government of States, Legislature of States, and All Local + Other Authorities - the components that constitute 'State'.

quiz.prompt: Private bodies performing public functions may be considered 'State' if:
options: They are under deep and pervasive government control
quiz.reason: Private bodies can be considered 'State' under Article 36 if they are under deep and pervasive government control and perform public functions, as established in Zee Telefilms case.

quiz.prompt: Article 36 is significant because:
quiz.reason: Article 36 is crucial because it defines who constitutes the 'State' for the purpose of implementing and enforcing the Directive Principles of State Policy.

quiz.prompt: Which of these bodies would typically NOT be considered 'State' under Article 36?
quiz.reason: A private school would not typically be considered 'State' unless it is under government control. LIC and Railway Board are government-controlled entities, and Municipal Corporation is a local authority.

quiz.prompt: The context rule in Article 36 allows:
options: Flexible interpretation based on article context
quiz.reason: The 'unless context otherwise requires' clause allows for flexible interpretation of 'State' depending on the specific context and requirements of different DPSP articles.

quiz.prompt: Article 36 and Article 12 are often called:
quiz.reason: Articles 12 and 36 are called 'twin articles' because they define the same meaning of 'State', with Article 36 applying this definition to DPSP.

quiz.prompt: Which amendment led to the inclusion of 'other authorities' in the definition of 'State'?
quiz.reason: The 42nd Amendment (1976) added 'other authorities' to the definition of 'State' in Article 12, which is applicable to Article 36 as well.

quiz.prompt: The definition of 'State' under Article 36 is:
quiz.reason: Article 36 explicitly states that it uses the same meaning of 'State' as Article 12, subject to the context rule.

subTopics.title: Article 37 ‚Äî Nature of DPSP
subTopics.description: Article 37 declares DPSP as fundamental but non-enforceable by courts.

content.heading: ARTICLE 37 ‚Äî THE HEART OF DPSP
content.body: The provisions in Part IV (DPSP) are not enforceable by any court, yet they are 'fundamental in the governance of the country' and it is the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.
highlights: Not enforceable by any court (Court's door closed)
DUTY of the State to apply these principles in law-making

content.title: Three Core Parts
points: 1) NOT enforceable by any court (Court's door closed)
3) DUTY of the State to apply these principles in law-making

content.title: Plain Meaning
points: DPSP = Aspirational goals for State to follow, not immediate legal rights for citizens.
Enforcement path = political/electoral ("Court of People"), not judicial.

content.title: Why Non-Enforceable
points: Financial constraints of a newly independent India (1950).
Progressive realization ‚Äî goals to be achieved over time, not instantly.
Separation of powers ‚Äî courts should not replace policy-making.
Tej Bahadur Sapru Committee recommended non-justiciability to avoid judicial overload.

content.title: Why Fundamental
points: DPSP provide the moral and policy foundation for social & economic justice.
They aim to create a welfare state and fill the 'social & economic' side of democracy.
They serve as the conscience/guide for governance and legislation.

content.title: Key Phrases
points: Nevertheless fundamental in the governance of the country
Duty of the State to apply these principles in law-making
Court of People (elections) ‚Äî enforcement through politics

content.title: Practice Impact
points: Courts cannot issue writs to force implementation of DPSP alone.
Parliament & State Legislatures must frame laws keeping DPSP in view.
DPSP often used to interpret and expand Fundamental Rights harmoniously.

breakdown.meaning: Duty of the State to apply
FR door open, DPSP door closed; foundation still essential

content.title: One-Liner
points: Article 37 = 'Fundamental in governance, but non-enforceable; State must apply.'

content.heading: Article 37 Flow
content.body:
Article 37
‚îú‚îÄ Part A: Not enforceable (Court ‚ùå)
‚îú‚îÄ Part B: Fundamental in governance (Base/Foundation ‚úÖ)
‚îî‚îÄ Part C: Duty of the State to apply in law-making (Action ‚Üí Laws)

content.heading: DPSP vs FR Enforcement
content.body:
[DPSP (Part IV)]
            |
   ----------------------
   |                    |
 [Court]           [State / People]
  (Can't enforce)   (Must apply; vote enforce)

content.title: Key Cases
points: State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan (1951) ‚Äî Early view ‚Äî DPSP cannot override Fundamental Rights. Resulted in constitutional amendments to allow specific state measures.
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973) ‚Äî FR and DPSP are complementary; Parliament can amend FR to implement DPSP but basic structure must be preserved.
Minerva Mills v. Union of India (1980) ‚Äî Balance between Part III (FR) and Part IV (DPSP) is part of the Basic Structure; neither should have absolute primacy.
Unnikrishnan v. State of AP (1993) & Mohini Jain (1992) ‚Äî Courts used DPSP to interpret and expand FR (Right to Education flows from Article 21 with DPSP support).

content.title: Judicial Evolution
points: Judicial approach evolved: Subordinate ‚Üí Complementary ‚Üí Harmonious balance ‚Üí Use DPSP to enrich FR through interpretation.

flashcards.front: What does Article 37 declare about DPSP?
flashcards.back: They are not enforceable by any court but are fundamental in the governance of the country and the State must apply them in making laws.

flashcards.front: What are the three parts of Article 37?
flashcards.back: 1) Not enforceable by courts, 2) Fundamental in governance, 3) Duty of State to apply in law-making.

flashcards.front: How are DPSP enforced if not by court?
flashcards.back: Through political/electoral mechanisms ‚Äî the 'Court of People' (voting, manifestos).

quiz.prompt: Article 37 declares DPSP as:
options: B) Fundamental in governance but not enforceable
quiz.reason: Article 37 states that DPSP are fundamental in governance but not enforceable by any court.

quiz.prompt: Which phrase is used in Article 37?
quiz.reason: Article 37 explicitly uses 'not enforceable by any court'.

quiz.prompt: The duty of the State in Article 37 is to:
options: C) Apply DPSP principles in law-making
D) Convert DPSP into Fundamental Rights immediately
quiz.reason: Article 37 states that it is the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.

quiz.prompt: Assertion: DPSP are fundamental in governance. Reason: DPSP are enforceable in courts.
options: A) Both A and R true, R explains A
B) Both A and R true, R doesn't explain A
quiz.reason: Assertion is true (Article 37), but Reason is false (DPSP are not enforceable).

quiz.prompt: Explain in two lines why DPSP are non-enforceable but still fundamental.
options: They are non-enforceable because they are aspirational policy goals requiring progressive realization and policy flexibility; they are fundamental as they form the moral and constitutional basis for governance and law-making.
quiz.reason: This captures the essence of Article 37.
